entry.title: Algorithms to Live By
entry.summary:
A few weeks ago I started reading Algorithms to Live By: The Computer Science of Human Decisions and been fascinated by it ever since:

What should we do, or leave undone, in a day or a lifetime? How much messiness should we accept? What balance of the new and familiar is the most fulfilling? These may seem like uniquely human quandaries, but they are not. Computers, like us, confront limited space and time, so computer scientists have been grappling with similar problems for decades. And the solutions they‚Äôve found have much to teach us.

In a dazzlingly interdisciplinary work, Brian Christian and Tom Griffiths show how algorithms developed for computers also untangle very human questions. They explain how to have better hunches and when to leave things to chance, how to deal with overwhelming choices and how best to connect with others. From finding a spouse to finding a parking spot, from organizing one‚Äôs inbox to peering into the future, Algorithms to Live By transforms the wisdom of computer science into strategies for human living.

I‚Äôll try and give you a little taste of the book - which I‚Äôm still reading (more precisely, listening), so you‚Äôll know what you‚Äôre getting into.

entry.title: Making Hexo Blazing Fast
entry.summary:
A week ago I migrated my blog from Ghost to Hexo to gain better performance and save money.

Hexo is said to be ‚ÄúBlazing Fast‚Äù, but while I did ‚Äúfeel‚Äù that my Hexo based site was snappier than its predecessor, it was far from ‚ÄúBlazing Fast‚Äù.

Performance is extremely important. There are a lot of articles on the subject, most of which point out that website performance & uptime are key to user satisfaction. WebpageFX wrote a nice summary of the subject - Why Website Speed is Important.

I‚Äôm not a web developer, and have almost zero knowledge in website optimizations. Nonetheless, I‚Äôve optimized more then a few apps in my career and know how to approach such problems.

All I need is to figure out the tooling to find the bottlenecks and fix them to gain good enough performance. That is, I‚Äôm not looking into optimizing every single piece of the website, only making it fast enough so it‚Äôll feel snappy.

This blog post explains the steps I took in order to dramatically decrease the average page size to less then 350k.

entry.title: From Ghost to Hexo
entry.summary:
After a few months of hosting my blog at DigitalOcean, I decided to ditch Ghost.
Instead, I‚Äôm moving my blog to Hexo, hosted by GitHub Pages.

TL;DR -

  • Ghost doesn‚Äôt offer any server features, but runs one.
  • Ghost wasn‚Äôt fast enough.
  • Unnecessary Server costs.
  • To much Maintenance.

entry.title: coroutines: basic building blocks for concurrency
entry.summary:
This part of the series explains the basic building block that allow writing concurrent programs in python.

Later in the series I‚Äôll show how to use different async paradigms using the new async syntax that was (finally) introduced in Python 3.5.

Prerequisites

  1. You‚Äôre using python 3.6.x
  2. You‚Äôre familiar with coroutines. otherwise, read - coroutines: Introduction.
    • You might also want to read the previous blog post: coroutines: Pipelines & Data flow

entry.title: Running, Editing & Debugging .NET Core Apps Inside a Container
entry.summary:
Today I needed to add a few features to an existing .NET Core application. I‚Äôm running Fedora 25, but that shouldn‚Äôt be an issue, right? because -

It appears that it doesn‚Äôt love Fedora 25, because it‚Äôs still not officially supported. Instead of hacking around and trying to get this thing working, and wasting my whole day doing so, I thought - why not use Docker?

The idea was simple - create a container that fires up Visual Studio Code inside a container that has .NET Core installed.

entry.title: names generator √† la docker
entry.summary:
I really like docker‚Äôs names generator. It makes remembering id‚Äôs easier, and as of version 0.7.x, it generates names from notable scientists and hackers, which gives it an extra bonus!

There are a number of ports out there (shamrin/namesgenerator for example), but all of them just copy-and-paste the names, which is not cool at all.

I decided to parse names-generator.go and extract the names from it, thus making sure it‚Äôs always up to date.

I wrote two implementations, one in python and one in go.

  • python: parses the code directly using regular expressions
  • go: parses the code using go‚Äôs AST package, and spit python code to stdout.

^ The hyperlinks lead to the relevant section in the blog post.

The amount of lines needed to do all that work is relatively short, which shows how powerful these languages are.
